body:
# AVLTree

[![GitHub release](https://img.shields.io/github/release/ngng628/avltree.svg)](https://github.com/ngng628/avltree/releases) [![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-red.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)


An implement of `SortedSet`, `SortedMap` and `SortedMultiset` using [AVL tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVL_tree).

Each method is implemented to be as compliant as possible with the standard `Set` and `Hash` in the Crystal language.

## :arrow_down: Installation

1. Add the dependency to your `shard.yml`:

   ```yaml
   dependencies:
     avltree:
       github: ngng628/avltree
   ```

2. Run `shards install`

## :pencil2: Usage

```crystal
require "avltree"
```

## :bulb: Sample

If you want more details, please refer to the API documentation.

```crystal
set = AVLTree::SortedSet(Int32).new
set << 3 << 1 << 4 << 1 << 5 << 9

set # => SortedSet{1, 3, 4, 5, 9}

set[0] # => 1
set[1] # => 3
set[2] # => 4  (SortedSet#[k] returns the kth object)

set.lower_bound(-1) # => 0
set.lower_bound(2) # => 1
set.lower_bound(3) # => 1
set.lower_bound(9) # => 4
set.lower_bound(10) # => 5

set.delete(1)
set # => SortedSet{3, 4, 5, 9}
```

```crystal
map = AVLTree::SortedMap(String, Int32).new

map["alice"] = 10
map["alice"] # => 10
map["carol"] = 20
map["carol"] # => 20
map["bob"] = -10
map["bob"] # => -10

map.at(0) # => {"alice", 10}
map.at(1) # => {"bob", -10}
map.at(2) # => {"carol", 20}  (at(k) returns the key-value pair to the kth key.)

map.lower_bound("a") # => 0
map.lower_bound("bob") # => 1
map.lower_bound("dave") # => 3

map.delete("alice")
map # {"bob" => -10, "carol" => 20}
map.delete_at(1)
map # {"bob" => -10}
```

```crystal
mset = AVLTree::SortedMultiset(Int32).new
mset << 3 << 1 << 4 << 1 << 5 << 9

mset # => SortedMultiset{1, 1, 3, 4, 5, 9}

mset[0] # => 1
mset[1] # => 1
mset[2] # => 3  (SortedMultiset#[k] returns the kth object)

mset.lower_bound(-1) # => 0
mset.lower_bound(2) # => 2
mset.lower_bound(3) # => 2
mset.lower_bound(9) # => 5
mset.lower_bound(10) # => 6

mset.delete(1)
mset # => SortedMultiset{1, 3, 4, 5, 9}
```


## :busts_in_silhouette: Contributing

1. Fork it (<https://github.com/ngng628/avltree/fork>)
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -am ':sparkles: Add some feature'`)
   - Please follow the `.gitmessage` format for the commit message.
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
5. Create a new Pull Request

## :desktop_computer: Contributors

- [ngng628](https://github.com/ngng628) - creator and maintainer

types.name: SortedMap
types.doc:
`SortedMap` implements a associative array that guarantees that its keys are yielded in sorted order
(according to the return keys of their #<=> methods) when iterating over them.

SortedMap is implemented using an AVL tree.

While it often has slower computational speed compared to a Hash implemented using a hash-based approach,
it offers potential optimizations for operations related to order.
For example, retrieving the maximum and minimum keys of the map can be performed in logarithmic time.

`SortedMap` does not allow duplicates and only stores unique keys.

### Example

```
require "avltree"

map = AVLTree::SortedMap(String, Int32).new({"bob" => 3, "alice" => 1, "carol" => -2})
map.to_a == [{"alice", 1}, {"bob", 3}, {"carol", -2}] # => true
map.to_a == [{"bob", 3}, {"alice", 1}, {"carol", -2}] # => false

map["dave"] = 4
map["oscar"] = 3

map # => {alice => 1, bob => 3, carol => -2, dave => 4, oscar => 3}

map.min # => {"alice", 1}  (O(logN))
map.max # => {"oscar", 3}  (O(logN))

map.lower_bound("a")     # => 0  (O(logN))
map.lower_bound("bryan") # => 2  (O(logN))
map.lower_bound("zoe")   # => 5  (O(logN))
```
types.summary: SortedMap implements a associative array that guarantees that its keys are yielded in sorted order (according to the return keys of their #<=> methods) when iterating over them.

def.name: zip
def.body:
map = self.new
ary1.zip(ary2) do |key, value|
  map[key] = value
end
map

def.name: new
def.body:
map = self.new
hash.each do |key, value|
  map[key] = value
end
map

if size == other.size
else
  return false
end
other.unordered_each do |key, value|
  node = find_node(@root, key)
  if node.nil?
    return false
  end
  if node.key != key
    return false
  end
  if node.value != value
    return false
  end
end
true

fetch(key) do
  if (block = @block) && key.is_a?(K)
    block.call(self, key.as(K))
  else
    raise(KeyError.new("Missing hash key: #{key.inspect}"))
  end
end

instance_methods.doc: Returns the key-value at the *index*-th.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the key-value at the index-th.

instance_methods.doc:
Like `at`, but returns `nil`
if trying to access an key-value outside the set's range.
instance_methods.summary: Like #at, but returns nil if trying to access an key-value outside the set's range.

def.name: clone
def.body:
map = SortedMap(K, V).new
unordered_each do |key, value|
  map[key] = value.clone
end
map

def.name: compact
def.body:
each_with_object(SortedMap(K, V).new) do |__arg47, memo|
  key = __arg47[0]
  value = __arg47[1]
  if value.nil?
  else
    memo[key] = value
  end
end

def.name: delete
def.body:
entry = delete_impl(key)
entry ? entry[1] : yield key

def.name: delete_at
def.body:
key = key_at(index)
if key.nil?
  return yield index
end
entry = delete_impl(key)
entry ? entry : yield index

def.name: delete_at
def.body:
key = key_at(index)
entry = delete_impl(key)
if entry.nil?
  raise(IndexError.new)
end
entry

def.name: delete_at?
def.body:
key = key_at?(index)
if key.nil?
  return nil
end
delete_impl(key)

dig?

def.name: each
def.body:
iter = ItemIterator(K, V).new(self)
iter.each do |key_and_value|
  yield key_and_value
end

iter.each do |key|

def.body:
iter = ValueIterator(K, V).new(self)
iter.each do |value|
  yield value
end

instance_methods.name: empty?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if `self` is empty, `false` otherwise.

```
([] of Int32).empty? # => true
([1]).empty?         # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if self is empty, false otherwise.

def.name: fetch
def.body:
node = find_node(@root, key)
if node && (node.key == key)
  node.value
else
  yield key
end

def.name: fetch_at
def.body:
if index < 0
  index = index + size
end
if 0 <= index && index < size
else
  return yield index
end
unsafe_fetch(index)

def.name: first_key
def.body: first_node.try(&.key) || (raise("Can't get first key of empty SortedMap"))

def.name: first_value
def.body: first_node.try(&.value) || (raise("Can't get first value of empty SortedMap"))

def.name: greater_item_with_index
has_key?
def.body:
if @root.nil?
  return false
end
node = find_node(@root, key)
(!node.nil?) && (node.key == key)

def.name: has_value?
def.body:
each_value do |v|
  if v == value
    return true
  end
end
false

def.name: index
def.body:
item, index = less_equal_item_with_index(key)
index && (item.try(&.[](0)) == key) ? index : nil

def.name: index!
def.body:
item, index = less_equal_item_with_index(key)
if index.nil?
  raise(Enumerable::NotFoundError.new)
end
item.try(&.[](0)) == key ? index : raise(Enumerable::NotFoundError.new)

instance_methods.name: inspect
instance_methods.doc:
Appends a String representation of this object
which includes its class name, its object address
and the values of all instance variables.

```
class Person
  def initialize(@name : String, @age : Int32)
  end
end

Person.new("John", 32).inspect # => #<Person:0x10fd31f20 @name="John", @age=32>
```
instance_methods.summary: Appends a String representation of this object which includes its class name, its object address and the values of all instance variables.

def.name: invert
def.body:
map = SortedMap(V, K)
each do |key, value|
  map[value] = key
end
map

def.body:
ret = fetch_at(index, nil)
if ret.nil?
  raise(IndexError.new)
else
  ret[0]
end

def.name: key_for
def.body:
key_for(value) do
  raise(KeyError.new("Missing hash key for value: #{value}"))
end

def.name: key_for
def.body:
each do |k, v|
  if v == value
    return k
  end
end
yield value

def.body: last_node.try(&.key) || (raise("Can't get last key of empty SortedMap"))

def.body: last_node.try(&.value) || (raise("Can't get last value of empty SortedMap"))

instance_methods.name: max
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element with the maximum value in the collection.

It compares using `>` so it will work for any type that supports that method.

```
[1, 2, 3].max        # => 3
["Alice", "Bob"].max # => "Bob"
```

Raises `Enumerable::EmptyError` if the collection is empty.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element with the maximum value in the collection.

def.name: max
def.body:
node = last_node
if node.nil?
  return nil
end
{node.key, node.value}

instance_methods.name: min
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element with the minimum value in the collection.

It compares using `<` so it will work for any type that supports that method.

```
[1, 2, 3].min        # => 1
["Alice", "Bob"].min # => "Alice"
```

Raises `Enumerable::EmptyError` if the collection is empty.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element with the minimum value in the collection.

def.name: min
def.body:
node = first_node
if node.nil?
  return nil
end
{node.key, node.value}

def.name: pop
def.body:
key = key_at?(size - 1)
if key
  delete(key)
else
  yield
end

def.name: put
def.body:
updated_item = upsert(key, value)
updated_item ? updated_item[1] : yield key

instance_methods.name: reject
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an `Array` with all the elements in the collection for which
the passed block is falsey.

```
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6].reject { |i| i % 2 == 0 } # => [1, 3, 5]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns an Array with all the elements in the collection for which the passed block is falsey.

def.name: reject
def.body:
each_with_object(SortedMap(K, V).new) do |__arg49, memo|
  key = __arg49[0]
  value = __arg49[1]
  if yield key, value
  else
    memo[key] = value
  end
end

def.name: reject!
def.body:
each do |key, value|
  if yield key, value
    delete(key)
  end
end
self

def.name: reverse_each
def.body:
iter = ReverseItemIterator(K, V).new(self)
iter.each do |key_and_value|
  yield key_and_value
end

def.name: reverse_each_key
def.body:
iter = ReverseKeyIterator(K, V).new(self)
iter.reverse_each do |key|
  yield key
end

def.name: reverse_each_value
def.body:
iter = ReverseValueIterator(K, V).new(self)
iter.reverse_each do |value|
  yield value
end

def.name: select
def.body:
keys.each_with_object(SortedMap(K, V).new) do |key, memo|
  value = self[key]?
  if value
    memo[key] = value
  end
end

def.name: select!
def.body:
each_key do |key|
  if k.in?(keys)
  else
    delete(key)
  end
end
self

def.name: select!
def.body:
key_set = keys.to_set
each_key do |k|
  if k.in?(key_set)
  else
    delete(k)
  end
end
self

def.name: shift
def.body:
key = key_at?(0)
if key
  delete(key)
else
  yield
end

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the number of elements in the collection.

```
[1, 2, 3, 4].size # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of elements in the collection.

def.name: subset_of?
def.body:
if other.size < size
  return false
end
all? do |key, value|
  other_value = other.fetch(key) do
    false
  end
  other_value == value
end

instance_methods.name: to_a
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an `Array` with all the elements in the collection.

```
(1..5).to_a # => [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns an Array with all the elements in the collection.

def.name: to_a
def.body:
ary = Array(::Tuple(K, V)).new(self.size)
each do |key, value|
  ary << {key, value}
end
ary

def.name: to_hash
def.body:
hash = Hash(K, V).new(@block)
each do |key, value|
  hash[key] = value
end
hash

instance_methods.name: to_s
instance_methods.doc:
Appends a short String representation of this object
which includes its class name and its object address.

```
class Person
  def initialize(@name : String, @age : Int32)
  end
end

Person.new("John", 32).to_s # => #<Person:0x10a199f20>
```
instance_methods.summary: Appends a short String representation of this object which includes its class name and its object address.

def.name: to_s
def.body:
io << "{"
each_with_index do |__arg63, i|
  key = __arg63[0]
  value = __arg63[1]
  if i != 0
    io << ", "
  end
  ((io << key) << " => ") << value
end
io << "}"

def.name: unordered_each
def.body:
if node.nil?
  return
end
next_node = Deque.new([node])
while !next_node.empty?
  now = next_node.shift
  yield({now.key, now.value})
  l = now.left
  if l
    next_node << l
  end
  r = now.right
  if r
    next_node << r
  end
end

def.name: unsafe_fetch
def.body:
node = @root
index = index + 1
while !node.nil?
  left_size = (node.try do |__arg39|
    __arg39.left.try(&.size)
  end || 0) + 1
  if left_size == index
    break
  end
  if index < left_size
    node = node.try(&.left)
  else
    node = node.try(&.right)
    index = index - left_size
  end
end
if node.nil?
  raise(IndexError.new)
else
  {node.key, node.value}
end

def.name: update
def.body:
if has_key?(key)
  self[key] = yield self[key]
else
  if block = @block
    default_value = block.call(self, key)
    upsert(key, yield default_value)
    defalut_value
  else
    raise(KeyError.new("Missing hash key: #{key.inspect}"))
  end
end

instance_methods.summary: Returns the value at the index-th.

def.name: value_at
def.body:

if ret.nil?
  raise(IndexError.new)
else
  ret[1]
end


def.name: reject

  value = __arg49[1]
  if yield key, value
  else
    memo[key] = value

end

def.name: rindex
def.body:
node, bound = upper_bound_impl(key)
if bound == size
  node = last_node
end
if node.nil?
  return nil
end
pre = node.prev
if pre.nil?
  return nil
end
pre.key == key ? bound - 1 : nil

def.name: rindex!
def.body:
node, bound = upper_bound_impl(key)
if bound == size
  node = last_node
end
if node.nil?
  raise(Enumerable::NotFoundError.new)
end
pre = node.prev
if pre.nil?
  raise(Enumerable::NotFoundError.new)
end
pre.key == key ? bound - 1 : raise(Enumerable::NotFoundError.new)

instance_methods.doc:
Appends a short String representation of this object
which includes its class name and its object address.

```
class Person
  def initialize(@name : String, @age : Int32)
  end
end

Person.new("John", 32).to_s # => #<Person:0x10a199f20>
```
instance_methods.summary: Appends a short String representation of this object which includes its class name and its object address.

def.name: to_s
def.body:
io << "{"
each_with_index do |__arg63, i|
  key = __arg63[0]
  value = __arg63[1]
  if i != 0
    io << ", "
  end
  ((io << key) << " => ") << value
end
io << "}"

def.name: unordered_each
def.body:
if node.nil?
  return
end
next_node = Deque.new([node])
while !next_node.empty?
  now = next_node.shift
  yield({now.key, now.value})
  l = now.left
  if l
    next_node << l
  end
  r = now.right
  if r
    next_node << r
  end
end

def.name: unsafe_fetch
def.body:
node = @root
index = index + 1
loop do
  left_size = (node.try do |__arg39|
    __arg39.left.try(&.size)
  end || 0) + 1
  if left_size == index
    break
  end
  if index < left_size
    node = node.try(&.left)
  else
    node = node.try(&.right)
    index = index - left_size
  end
end
if node.nil?
  raise(NilAssertionError.new)
else
  {node.key, node.value}
end

def.name: update
def.body:
if has_key?(key)
  self[key] = yield self[key]
else
  if block = @block
    default_value = block.call(self, key)
    upsert(key, yield default_value)
    defalut_value
  else
    raise(KeyError.new("Missing hash key: #{key.inspect}"))
  end
end

types.name: SortedMultiset
types.doc:
`SortedMultiset` implements a collection of sorted values with possible duplicates.

### Sample

```
require "avltree"

mset = AVLTree::SortedMultiset(Int32).new
mset << 3 << 1 << 4 << 1 << 5 << 9

mset # => SortedMultiset{1, 1, 3, 4, 5, 9}

mset[0] # => 1
mset[1] # => 1
mset[2] # => 3  (SortedMultiset#[k] returns the kth object)

mset.lower_bound(-1) # => 0
mset.lower_bound(2)  # => 2
mset.lower_bound(3)  # => 2
mset.lower_bound(9)  # => 5
mset.lower_bound(10) # => 6

mset.delete(1)
mset # => SortedMultiset{1, 3, 4, 5, 9}
```
types.summary: SortedMultiset implements a collection of sorted values with possible duplicates.

def.body:
smallest, largest = self, other
if largest.size < smallest.size
  smallest, largest = largest, smallest
end
set = SortedMultiset(T).new
smallest.each do |value|
  if largest.includes?(value)
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedMultiset(T).new
unordered_each do |value|
  if other.includes?(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedMultiset(T | U).new
unordered_each do |value|
  if other.includes?(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
other.unordered_each do |value|
  if includes?(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedMultiset(T | U).new(self)
other.unordered_each do |value|
  if includes?(value)
    set.delete(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedMultiset(T | U).new
unordered_each do |value|
  set << value
end
other.unordered_each do |value|
  set << value
end
set

instance_methods.name: count
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the number of elements in the set that exist within the range

```
set = AVLTree::SortedSet(Int32){3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9}
set.count(0..1).should eq 2
set.count(0...1).should eq 0
set.count(0..2).should eq 2
set.count(0...2).should eq 2
set.count(2..3).should eq 1
set.count(2...3).should eq 0
set.count(2..9).should eq 4
set.count(2...9).should eq 3
set.count(2...).should eq 4
set.count(...).should eq 6
set.count(...9).should eq 5
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of elements in the set that exist within the range

def.name: count
def.body:
b, e = range.begin, range.end
left = b ? lower_bound(b) : 0
right = if e.nil?
  size
else
  if range.exclusive?
    lower_bound(e)
  else
    upper_bound(e)
  end
end
right - left

instance_methods.name: dup

Because `Value` is a value type, this method returns `self`,
which already involves a shallow copy of this object because
value types are passed by value.

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.doc:
Calls the given block once for each element in `self`, passing that
element as a parameter.

```
a = ["a", "b", "c"]
a.each { |x| print x, " -- " }
```

produces:

```text
a -- b -- c --
```
instance_methods.summary: Calls the given block once for each element in self, passing that element as a parameter.

instance_methods.summary: Returns true if self is empty, false otherwise.

instance_methods.name: fetch
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element at the given *index*, if in bounds,
otherwise executes the given block with the index and returns its value.

```
a = [:foo, :bar]
a.fetch(0) { :default_value }    # => :foo
a.fetch(2) { :default_value }    # => :default_value
a.fetch(2) { |index| index * 3 } # => 6
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element at the given index, if in bounds, otherwise executes the given block with the index and returns its value.

ret.nil? ? default : ret[0]

instance_methods.name: rindex
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the index of the last appearance of *value* in `self`, or
`nil` if the value is not in `self`.

If *offset* is given, it defines the position to _end_ the search
(elements beyond this point are ignored).

```
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2)            # => 3
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2, offset: 2) # => 1
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the index of the last appearance of value in self, or nil if the value is not in self.

`nil` if the value is not in `self`.

(elements beyond this point are ignored).

```
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2)            # => 3
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2, offset: 2) # => 1
```

Raises `Enumerable::NotFoundError` if *value* is not in `self`.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the index of the last appearance of value in self, or nil if the value is not in self.

instance_methods.name: unsafe_fetch
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element at the given *index*, without doing any bounds check.

`Indexable` makes sure to invoke this method with *index* in `0...size`,
so converting negative indices to positive ones is not needed here.

Clients never invoke this method directly. Instead, they access
elements with `#[](index)` and `#[]?(index)`.

This method should only be directly invoked if you are absolutely
sure the index is in bounds, to avoid a bounds check for a small boost
of performance.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element at the given index, without doing any bounds check.

types.name: SortedSet
types.doc:
`SortedSet` implements a Set that guarantees that its elements are yielded in sorted order
(according to the return values of their #<=> methods) when iterating over them.

`SortedSet` utilizes an internally implemented `SortedMap` using an AVL tree.

While it often has slower computational speed compared to a Set implemented using a hash-based approach,
it offers potential optimizations for operations related to order.
For example, retrieving the maximum and minimum values of the set can be performed in logarithmic time.

`SortedSet` does not allow duplicates and only stores unique values.

### Example

```
require "avltree"

set = AVLTree::SortedSet.new [3, 1, 4]
set.to_a == [1, 3, 4] # => true
set.to_a == [3, 1, 4] # => false

set << 1 << 5
set                 # => SortedSet{1, 3, 4, 5}
set.min             # => 1  (O(logN))
set.max             # => 5  (O(logN))
set.index(4)        # => 2  (O(logN))
set.upper_bound(2)  # => 1  (O(logN))
set.upper_bound(3)  # => 1  (O(logN))
set.upper_bound(10) # => 4  (O(logN))
```
types.summary: SortedSet implements a Set that guarantees that its elements are yielded in sorted order (according to the return values of their #<=> methods) when iterating over them.

def.body:
smallest, largest = self, other
if largest.size < smallest.size
  smallest, largest = largest, smallest
end
set = SortedSet(T).new
smallest.each do |value|
  if largest.includes?(value)
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedSet(T).new
unordered_each do |value|
  if other.includes?(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedSet(T | U).new
unordered_each do |value|
  if other.includes?(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
other.unordered_each do |value|
  if includes?(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedSet(T | U).new(self)
other.each do |value|
  if includes?(value)
    set.delete(value)
  else
    set << value
  end
end
set

set = SortedSet(T | U).new
unordered_each do |value|
  set << value
end
other.unordered_each do |value|
  set << value
end
set

instance_methods.name: count
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the number of elements in the set that exist within the range.

```
set = AVLTree::SortedSet(Int32){3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9}
set.count(2..3)  # => 1
set.count(2...3) # => 0
set.count(2..9)  # => 4
set.count(2...9) # => 3
set.count(2...)  # => 4
set.count(...)   # => 5
set.count(...9)  # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of elements in the set that exist within the range.

def.name: count
def.body:
b, e = range.begin, range.end
left = b ? lower_bound(b) : 0
right = if e.nil?
  size
else
  if range.exclusive?
    lower_bound(e)
  else
    upper_bound(e)
  end
end
right - left

instance_methods.name: count
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the number of times that the passed item is present in the collection.

```
[1, 2, 3, 4].count(3) # => 1
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of times that the passed item is present in the collection.

instance_methods.name: delete
instance_methods.doc: Removes the object from the set and returns `true` if it was present, otherwise returns `false`.
instance_methods.summary: Removes the object from the set and returns true if it was present, otherwise returns false.

instance_methods.name: delete_at
instance_methods.doc: Removes the *index*-th object and returns the deleted object, else yields `index` with given block.
instance_methods.summary: Removes the index-th object and returns the deleted object, else yields #index with given block.

def.name: delete_at
def.body:
entry = @map.delete_at?(index)
if entry.nil?
  return yield index
end
entry[0]

instance_methods.name: delete_at
instance_methods.doc: Removes the *index*-th object from the set and returns the deleted object.
instance_methods.summary: Removes the index-th object from the set and returns the deleted object.

instance_methods.name: delete_at?
instance_methods.doc: Removes the *index*-th object from the set and returns the deleted object if it was present, otherwise returns nil.
instance_methods.summary: Removes the index-th object from the set and returns the deleted object if it was present, otherwise returns nil.

instance_methods.name: dup
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a shallow copy of this object.

Because `Value` is a value type, this method returns `self`,
which already involves a shallow copy of this object because
value types are passed by value.
instance_methods.summary: Returns a shallow copy of this object.

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.doc:
Calls the given block once for each element in `self`, passing that
element as a parameter.

```
a = ["a", "b", "c"]
a.each { |x| print x, " -- " }
```

produces:

```text
a -- b -- c --
```
instance_methods.summary: Calls the given block once for each element in self, passing that element as a parameter.

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.doc: Must return an `Iterator` over the elements in this collection.
instance_methods.summary: Must return an Iterator over the elements in this collection.

instance_methods.name: empty?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if `self` is empty, `false` otherwise.

```
([] of Int32).empty? # => true
([1]).empty?         # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if self is empty, false otherwise.

instance_methods.name: fetch
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element at the given *index*, if in bounds,
otherwise executes the given block with the index and returns its value.

```
a = [:foo, :bar]
a.fetch(0) { :default_value }    # => :foo
a.fetch(2) { :default_value }    # => :default_value
a.fetch(2) { |index| index * 3 } # => 6
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element at the given index, if in bounds, otherwise executes the given block with the index and returns its value.

def.name: fetch
def.body:
ret = @map.fetch_at(index) do
  nil
end
ret.nil? ? yield index : ret[0]

def.name: fetch
def.body:
ret = @map.fetch_at(index) do
  nil
end
ret.nil? ? default : ret[0]

instance_methods.name: first
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the first element in the collection. Raises `Enumerable::EmptyError`
if the collection is empty.

```
([1, 2, 3]).first   # => 1
([] of Int32).first # raises Enumerable::EmptyError
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the first element in the collection.

instance_methods.name: first?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the first element in the collection.
When the collection is empty, returns `nil`.

```
([1, 2, 3]).first?   # => 1
([] of Int32).first? # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the first element in the collection.

instance_methods.name: greater_equal_index
instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#greater_equal_index`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#greater_equal_index

instance_methods.name: greater_equal_object
instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#greater_equal_item`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#greater_equal_item

instance_methods.name: greater_equal_object_with_index
instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#greater_equal_item_with_index`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#greater_equal_item_with_index

instance_methods.name: greater_index
instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#greater_index`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#greater_index

instance_methods.name: greater_object
instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#greater_item`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#greater_item

instance_methods.name: greater_object_with_index
instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#greater_item_with_index`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#greater_item_with_index

instance_methods.name: hash
instance_methods.doc: See `Object#hash(hasher)`
instance_methods.summary: See Object#hash(hasher)

instance_methods.name: includes?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if the collection contains *obj*, `false` otherwise.

```
[1, 2, 3].includes?(2) # => true
[1, 2, 3].includes?(5) # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if the collection contains obj, false otherwise.

instance_methods.name: index
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the index of the first appearance of *object* in `self`
starting from the given *offset*, or `nil` if *object* is not in `self`.

```
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3].index(2, offset: 2) # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the index of the first appearance of object in self starting from the given offset, or nil if object is not in self.

instance_methods.name: index!
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the index of the first appearance of *obj* in `self`
starting from the given *offset*. Raises `Enumerable::NotFoundError` if
*obj* is not in `self`.

```
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3].index!(2, offset: 2) # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the index of the first appearance of obj in self starting from the given offset.

instance_methods.name: inspect
instance_methods.doc:
Appends this struct's name and instance variables names and values
to the given IO.

```
struct Point
  def initialize(@x : Int32, @y : Int32)
  end
end

p1 = Point.new 1, 2
p1.to_s    # "Point(@x=1, @y=2)"
p1.inspect # "Point(@x=1, @y=2)"
```
instance_methods.summary: Appends this struct's name and instance variables names and values to the given IO.

def.name: intersects?
def.body:
if size < other.size
  any? do |o|
    other.includes?(o)
  end
else
  other.any? do |o|
    includes?(o)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: last
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the last element of `self` if it's not empty, or raises `IndexError`.

```
([1, 2, 3]).last   # => 3
([] of Int32).last # raises IndexError
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the last element of self if it's not empty, or raises IndexError.

instance_methods.name: last?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the last element of `self` if it's not empty, or `nil`.

```
([1, 2, 3]).last?   # => 3
([] of Int32).last? # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the last element of self if it's not empty, or nil.

instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#less_equal_index`
instance_methods.summary: See SortedMap#less_equal_index

instance_methods.doc: See `SortedMap#less_equal_item`

instance_methods.name: lower_bound
instance_methods.doc:
```
set = AVLTree::SortedSet(String){"A", "B", "B", "C", "E"}
set                  # => SortedSet{"A", "B", "C", "E"}
set.lower_bound("@") # => 0
set.lower_bound("A") # => 0
set.lower_bound("B") # => 1
set.lower_bound("C") # => 2
set.lower_bound("D") # => 3
set.lower_bound("E") # => 3
set.lower_bound("F") # => 4
set.lower_bound("Z") # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: set = AVLTree::SortedSet(String){"A", "B", "B", "C", "E"} set # => SortedSet{"A", "B", "C", "E"} set.lower_bound("@") # => 0 set.lower_bound("A") # => 0 set.lower_bound("B") # => 1 set.lower_bound("C") # => 2 set.lower_bound("D") # => 3 set.lower_bound("E") # => 3 set.lower_bound("F") # => 4 set.lower_bound("Z") # => 4

instance_methods.name: max
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element with the maximum value in the collection.

It compares using `>` so it will work for any type that supports that method.

```
[1, 2, 3].max        # => 3
["Alice", "Bob"].max # => "Bob"
```

Raises `Enumerable::EmptyError` if the collection is empty.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element with the maximum value in the collection.

instance_methods.name: max?
instance_methods.doc: Like `max` but returns `nil` if the collection is empty.
instance_methods.summary: Like #max but returns nil if the collection is empty.

instance_methods.name: min
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element with the minimum value in the collection.

It compares using `<` so it will work for any type that supports that method.

```
[1, 2, 3].min        # => 1
["Alice", "Bob"].min # => "Alice"
```

Raises `Enumerable::EmptyError` if the collection is empty.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element with the minimum value in the collection.

instance_methods.name: min?
instance_methods.doc: Like `min` but returns `nil` if the collection is empty.
instance_methods.summary: Like #min but returns nil if the collection is empty.

def.name: pop
def.body:
object = last?
if object
  delete(object)
  object
else
  yield
end

def.name: proper_subset_of?
def.body:
if other.size <= size
  return false
end
all? do |value|
  other.includes?(value)
end

instance_methods.name: rindex
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the index of the last appearance of *value* in `self`, or
`nil` if the value is not in `self`.

If *offset* is given, it defines the position to _end_ the search
(elements beyond this point are ignored).

```
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2)            # => 3
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2, offset: 2) # => 1
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the index of the last appearance of value in self, or nil if the value is not in self.

instance_methods.name: rindex!
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the index of the last appearance of *value* in `self`, or
`nil` if the value is not in `self`.

If *offset* is given, it defines the position to _end_ the search
(elements beyond this point are ignored).

```
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2)            # => 3
[1, 2, 3, 2, 3].rindex(2, offset: 2) # => 1
```

Raises `Enumerable::NotFoundError` if *value* is not in `self`.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the index of the last appearance of value in self, or nil if the value is not in self.

def.name: shift
def.body:
object = first?
if object
  delete(object)
  object
else
  yield
end

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc: Returns the number of elements in this container.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of elements in this container.

def.name: subset_of?
def.body:
if other.size < size
  return false
end
all? do |value|
  other.includes?(value)
end

instance_methods.name: to_a
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an `Array` with all the elements in the collection.

```
{1, 2, 3}.to_a # => [1, 2, 3]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns an Array with all the elements in the collection.

instance_methods.name: to_s
instance_methods.doc: Same as `#inspect(io)`.
instance_methods.summary: Same as #inspect(io).

instance_methods.name: unordered_each
instance_methods.doc:
Yields each element of the set, and returns self.

It doesn't guarantee that its elements are yielded in sorted order when iterating over them.
instance_methods.summary: Yields each element of the set, and returns self.

instance_methods.name: unsafe_fetch
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the element at the given *index*, without doing any bounds check.

`Indexable` makes sure to invoke this method with *index* in `0...size`,
so converting negative indices to positive ones is not needed here.

Clients never invoke this method directly. Instead, they access
elements with `#[](index)` and `#[]?(index)`.

This method should only be directly invoked if you are absolutely
sure the index is in bounds, to avoid a bounds check for a small boost
of performance.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the element at the given index, without doing any bounds check.

instance_methods.name: upper_bound
instance_methods.doc:
```
set = AVLTree::SortedSet(String){"A", "B", "B", "C", "E"}
set                  # => SortedSet{"A", "B", "C", "E"}
set.upper_bound("@") # => 0
set.upper_bound("A") # => 1
set.upper_bound("B") # => 2
set.upper_bound("C") # => 3
set.upper_bound("D") # => 3
set.upper_bound("E") # => 4
set.upper_bound("F") # => 4
set.upper_bound("Z") # => 4
```
instance_methods.summary: set = AVLTree::SortedSet(String){"A", "B", "B", "C", "E"} set # => SortedSet{"A", "B", "C", "E"} set.upper_bound("@") # => 0 set.upper_bound("A") # => 1 set.upper_bound("B") # => 2 set.upper_bound("C") # => 3 set.upper_bound("D") # => 3 set.upper_bound("E") # => 4 set.upper_bound("F") # => 4 set.upper_bound("Z") # => 4

types.name: Enumerable
types.doc:
The `Enumerable` mixin provides collection classes with several traversal, searching,
filtering and querying methods.

Including types must provide an `each` method, which yields successive members
of the collection.

For example:

```
class Three
  include Enumerable(Int32)

  def each(&)
    yield 1
    yield 2
    yield 3
  end
end

three = Three.new
three.to_a                # => [1, 2, 3]
three.select &.odd?       # => [1, 3]
three.all? { |x| x < 10 } # => true
```

Note that most search and filter methods traverse an Enumerable eagerly,
producing an `Array` as the result. For a lazy alternative refer to
the `Iterator` and `Iterable` modules.
types.summary: The Enumerable mixin provides collection classes with several traversal, searching, filtering and querying methods.
